video.title: TEDTalks: Head Games
video.synopsis: Did you know scientists can see how you feel? Why are some of us susceptible to cults? These TED presenters discuss the complex world of behavior.

episodes.synopsis: We're lied to 10 to 200 times a day. The clues to detect a lie can be subtle and counterintuitive. Pamela Meyer shows how.
episodes.title: Pamela Meyer: How to Spot a Liar

episodes.synopsis: Tony Robbins discusses the "invisible forces" that motivate everyone's actions -- and high-fives Al Gore in the front row.
episodes.title: Tony Robbins Asks Why We Do What We Do

episodes.synopsis: A woman diagnosed with autism as a child explains how her mind works and why the world needs people on the autism spectrum.
episodes.title: Temple Grandin: The World Needs All Kinds of Minds

episodes.synopsis: Dan Gilbert challenges the idea that we'll be miserable if we don't get what we want.
episodes.title: Dan Gilbert Asks, Why Are We Happy?

episodes.synopsis: Most of us will do anything to avoid being wrong. Kathryn Schulz makes a case for embracing our fallibility.
episodes.title: Kathryn Schulz: On Being Wrong

episodes.synopsis: Ron Gutman reviews a raft of studies about smiling, and reveals some surprising results.
episodes.title: Ron Gutman: The Hidden Power of Smiling

episodes.synopsis: Philip Zimbardo talks about how easy it is for nice people to turn bad, and the flip side: how easy it is to be a hero.
episodes.title: Philip Zimbardo Shows How People Become Monsters... or Heroes

episodes.synopsis: A Nobel laureate reveals how our "experiencing selves" and our "remembering selves" perceive happiness differently.
episodes.title: Daniel Kahneman: The Riddle of Experience vs. Memory

episodes.synopsis: A neurologist explains Charles Bonnet syndrome -- when visually impaired people experience lucid hallucinations.
episodes.title: Oliver Sacks: What Hallucination Reveals About Our Minds

episodes.synopsis: The human tendency to believe strange things boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills.
episodes.title: Michael Shermer: The Pattern Behind Self-Deception

episodes.synopsis: As the field of psychology moves beyond a focus on disease, what can modern psychology help us to become?
episodes.title: Martin Seligman on Positive Psychology

episodes.synopsis: What makes psychopathic killers tick? A neuroscientist reveals the rotten wiring in the nature (and nurture) of murderers.
episodes.title: Jim Fallon: Exploring the Mind of a Killer

episodes.synopsis: An ex-"Moonie" explains the mind of a cult member, and proposes a new way to think about conflicts and extremist movements.
episodes.title: Diane Benscoter on How Cults Rewire the Brain

episodes.synopsis: Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio discusses the amazing state of human consciousness and gives us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self.
episodes.title: Antonio Damasio: The Quest to Understand Consciousness

episodes.synopsis: Scientist Tali Sharot shares new research that suggests our brains are wired to be optimistic -- and how that can be both dangerous and beneficial.
episodes.title: Tali Sharot: The Optimism Bias

episodes.synopsis: In this powerful talk, Elyn Saks asks us to see people with mental illness clearly, honestly and compassionately.
episodes.title: Elyn Saks: Seeing Mental Illness

episodes.synopsis: Is there a definitive line that divides crazy from sane? With a hair-raising delivery, writer Jon Ronson illuminates the gray areas between the two.
episodes.title: Jon Ronson: Strange Answers to the Psychopath Test

episodes.synopsis: With dazzling energy and humor, comedian Ruby Wax, diagnosed a decade ago with clinical depression, urges us to end the stigma of mental illness.
episodes.title: Ruby Wax: What's So Funny About Mental Illness?

episodes.synopsis: In developing countries, nearly 90 percent of people with mental illnesses go untreated because psychiatrists are in such short supply.
episodes.title: Vikram Patel: Mental Health for All by Involving All
